|Title=Knowing what cardiogenic acute pulmonary oedema (PAO) is
|Description=Left heart failure leading to transudative pulmonary oedema
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=Olivier Huttin
|Order=3}}
Pathophysiological definition:

- Sudden onset of acute respiratory distress associated with an increase in left ventricular filling pressure.

- CI leads to a sudden increase in left ventricular filling pressures. This increase in LV pressure is associated with an increase in pressure in the left atrium and pulmonary capillaries (> 25 mmHg). This pressure is higher than the interstitial oncotic pressure and results in the formation of a transudate in the pulmonary alveoli. The alveoli are "flooded" and haematosis is altered.

Remarks :

- OAP results in impaired gas exchange leading to hypoxaemia.

- It is associated with a compensatory mechanism resulting in hyperventilation, leading initially to hypocapnia.

- Clinical picture of acute respiratory failure associating :

o Dyspnoea with orthopnoea,

o Frothy expectoration

o Anxiety and agitation, sweating

o Peripheral cyanosis

o Crackles on pulmonary auscultation

This is a therapeutic emergency.

question.title: What is the primary cause of cardiogenic acute pulmonary oedema (PAO)?
question.description: A question about the underlying mechanism of PAO

option_a.title: Increased interstitial oncotic pressure
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect option related to fluid dynamics

option_b.title: Decreased left ventricular filling pressures
option_b.description: The opposite of the correct answer, creating ambiguity

option_c.title: Sudden increase in left ventricular filling pressures
option_c.description: The correct answer, but without additional context for clarification

option_d.title: Increased pulmonary artery pressure
option_d.description: A related but incorrect concept in the context of PAO

correct_option.title: C
correct_option.description: A single letter indicating the correct option
